title: Frostbite
summary: Freezing of body tissues, usually affecting fingers, toes, nose, and ears. Requires careful rewarming to prevent permanent damage.

steps.title: Identify Frostbite
steps.description: Skin appears white/grayish, is hard or waxy looking, and numb. First degree: skin is cold and red. Second degree: blisters form. Third degree: deep tissue involvement, skin appears white/blotchy.

steps.title: Get to Warm Area
steps.description: Move to warm room immediately. Handle affected areas gently. Do NOT walk on frostbitten feet unless necessary. Remove wet clothing and jewelry. Call 911 for severe frostbite.

steps.title: Protect the Area
steps.description: Do NOT thaw if refreezing is possible. Cover area with loose, dry dressings. Place gauze between affected fingers/toes. Don't disturb blisters. Wrap area loosely to protect from contact.

steps.title: Begin Rewarming if Safe
steps.description: If medical care is not available within 2 hours, rewarm in warm (not hot) water 98-102Â°F for 15-30 minutes. Test temperature with unaffected hand. Severe pain during rewarming is normal.

steps.title: After Rewarming
steps.description: Apply loose bandages. Give over-the-counter pain medicine. Give warm liquids if conscious. Do NOT: rub area, use direct heat, smoke (reduces circulation), or disturb blisters. Seek medical care.

warnings: Never rub frostbitten areas - this causes more damage
Do not use direct heat like fires, heating pads, or stoves
Thawing and refreezing causes severe tissue damage
whenToSeekHelp: Seek medical care for all but minor frostbite
Call 911 for large areas or if skin is hard and doesn't move
Get immediate care if area remains numb after 30 minutes of rewarming
preventionTips: Dress in layers and keep dry in cold weather
Cover exposed skin and wear appropriate winter gear
Learn to recognize early warning signs like numbness
